runs.text: Explain that a plural noun stands for more than one of something. Many nouns add
to form the plural, as in
. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
. Point out the spelling changes when the plural is formed.
. Have students say a sentence for each word.
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different? Why?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: How Is Earth Changing?
Display the image on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words affects, concerned,consequences, shrinking, global, and continues, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Write these word pairs on the board:
Identify how the words are alike. Explain how plurals are formed by changing f/fe to ves. Then have students work with you to form the plurals of
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What syllables do you hear in
? (cer-tain) Theres a lot to remember with this word. It begins with the soft
is pronounced and spelled just like the last syllable in
. That can help us remember it.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Write these word pairs on the board:
Identify how the words are alike and explain how the plurals were formed. Point out the vowel spelling change. Then have students work with you to form the plurals of
Use the Lesson 2 blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
When completed, guide students to find and underline each irregular plural in which the vowel(s) changed
Then have them put a box around each irregular plural where the f was changed to a v
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
men, man, main, rain, raining (cumulative review)

Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Model how to make the words
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write on paper or a dry-erase board a sentence using both words.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.

Dictate the following words for students to spell:

. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
Remind students that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Review how to form some kinds of irregular plural nouns:
Change f or fe to ves.
Write the following words on the board. Model how to form the plural for each one.
Continue by having students form the plural of these words:
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
Encourage students to look for plurals that have been formed the same way. Highlight these words as you encounter them.
Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Write these word pairs on the board:
Identify how the words are alike and explain how the plurals were formed. Then have students work with you to form the plural of
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding -s or -es. Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Write these word pairs on the board:
Identify how the words are alike and explain how the plurals were formed (change vowel spelling).
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., I am certain that ____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
Explain that irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding
Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
Write these word pairs on the board:
Explain that students have to memorize these plurals. Then model forming the plurals of

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and underline all the irregular plural nouns that have to be memorized. Then have them put a box around each plural in which the vowel or vowels changed.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.

to make it plural. What word did you make?

Read Aloud: Storms Made of Sand and Dust

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Read Aloud: Blizzards Bring Snowand Danger
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words average, present, form, and occur, and check understanding.
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
. Remind students that they can use what they know about syllables and spelling patterns to read longer words.
Model identifying the closed syllables in
. Draw a line to divide the syllable,
. Have students blend the syllables and read the word. Repeat with
(ev/er). Focus on how to pronounce each syllable type (e.g., closed syllable has a short vowel sound).
(dis/card). Guide students to divide each word into syllables, read the syllables, then blend the syllables to read the words.
Replace the ending in fishing to make a word that means like a fish.
Delete the suffix in fishy to name a water animal that has gills.
Add three letters to the beginning of fish to make a word that means concerned only with yourself, not others.
Take away the suffix in selfish to make a word that means ones own being.
Change the ending of self to make the word plural.
Read, Build, Write: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
